Laboratory for Chemical Technology Ghent University Technologiepark 125 Zwijnaarde 9052 Belgium Graphical abstract Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 and Pt:In/MgAl2O4 catalysts with 3 wt% Pt and 3 wt% Sn or In were tested for CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation (CO2-PDH). This reaction was referenced against reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) and non-oxidative PDH, while CO-DRIFTS detailed the nanoparticle (NP) surface. Results were connected to a preceding study, focused on NP material properties using Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy and Temporal Analysis of Products. During CO2-PDH, CO2 was mainly consumed through RWGS. CO2 consumption beyond the RWGS equilibrium arose from carbon oxidation. Promoter oxidation by CO2 and the consequent loss of the Pt-based alloys induced carbon formation. This deactivation increased the in situ CO2:H2 ratio, further accelerating promoter oxidation and carbon formation. Repeated catalyst regeneration cycles increased the promoter concentration in the alloyed NPs. This occurred throughout the entire Pt:Sn NP, while for Pt:In, it was limited to the NP surface with concomitant NP bulk depletion. This promoter enrichment contributed to catalyst deactivation. Keywords CO2-PDH Reverse water–gas shift Carbon oxidation Platinum-indium alloy Platinum-tin alloy Promoter enrichment Supported metal catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene forms the foundation of numerous industrial processes and consumer productsthrough its direct use in polypropylene andits derivates. Examples of such derivatives include acrylonitrile, cumene, propylene oxide and acrylic acid.[1] The majority of the propylene supply is derived from steam cracking and catalytic cracking, both of which produce propylene as a byproduct.[1] Over the past two decades, a shift towards lighter feedstocks such as ethane has further decreased the propylene yield from these conventional processes.[2] This has stimulated the development of targeted propylene synthesis routes.[2–5] Among such selective processes, propane dehydrogenation (“PDH”, Eq. (1) ) accounts for nearly half of the targeted propylene production.[3,6] An established catalyst system for PDH consists of supported Pt nanoparticles (NPs). To suppress side reactions and deep dehydrogenation, Pt is often alloyed with a promoter metal such as Sn[7–11], In[12,13], Ga[14–16] or Ge[17,18]. Simultaneously, carbon formation and Pt sintering are mitigated. The resulting improved selectivity and stability reduce the need for frequent catalyst regeneration, as is still required in industrial PDH processes.[1,4,19–21] Catalyst regeneration typically consists of removing accumulated carbon in O2 at high temperatures, followed by a reduction in H2 to regain the metallic alloy phases between Pt and the promoter metal.[1] A more recent strategy pursuing further improvement entails co-feeding CO2 to the PDH process, termed “CO2-assisted PDH” or “CO2-PDH”.[3,22–24] This can enhance propylene formation through a chemical equilibrium shift, enabled by the consumption of produced H2 via the reverse water-gas shift reaction (“RWGS”, Eq. (2) ). Alternatively, a one-step interaction between CO2 and propane (Eq. (3) ) can produce propylene and CO.[24,25] In different stoichiometries, dry reforming of propane occurs as acompeting reaction (Eq. (4) ), producing syngas instead of propylene. CO2 can also oxidize accumulated carbon from the surface, forming CO (Eq. (5) ).[22] (1) C 3 H 8 ⇌ C 3 H 6 + H 2 Δ H 298 = + 124 k J m o l (2) C O 2 + H 2 ⇌ H 2 O + C O Δ H 298 = + 41 k J m o l (3) C O 2 + C 3 H 8 ⇌ C 3 H 6 + C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 = + 164 k J m o l (4) 3 C O 2 + C 3 H 8 ⇌ 6 C O + 4 H 2 Δ H 298 = + 620 k J m o l (5) C + C O 2 ⇌ 2 C O Δ H 298 = + 172 k J m o l CO2-PDH essentially yields propylene and H2, while CO2 is co-fed. As such, a redox environment arises. This can affect the catalyst material and adds complexity to the process and catalyst development when compared to non-oxidative PDH. A viable CO2-PDH process remains to be developed.[6] Research focuses mainly on oxide catalysts such as VOx, FeOx, InOx and GaOx.[3,6,22,24,26] Such catalysts often follow a Mars-Van Krevelen (“redox”) mechanism: the metal oxides are reduced in a dehydrogenation step and re-oxidized through dissociative adsorption of CO2. Catalyst systems resembling those used in industrial non-oxidative PDH processes (e.g. Oleflex[4]) have received less interest in the context of CO2-PDH, despite their potential for dehydrogenation activity and propylene selectivity. This includes bimetallic Pt-based catalysts with non-reducible supports and modifications thereof.[6,9,27–30] Past work showed that Pt-Sn/MgAl2O4 catalysts, i.e. bimetallic Pt-based catalysts with non-reducible support, are active for CO2-PDH. However, a precise understanding of the catalyst behaviour during CO2-PDH remains to be established.[23] As a first step in understanding the added complexity of the redox environment caused by CO2, a detailed structural characterization was undertaken on three Pt-based catalysts in preceding work[31]: Pt/MgAl2O4, Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 and Pt:In/MgAl2O4, henceforth named monometallic Pt, Pt:Sn and Pt:In, respectively. The targeted loadings were 3 wt% Pt and 3 wt% Sn or In. These promoters were selected based on their proven efficacy for non-oxidative PDH,[4,7,10,12,32–36] while the atomic (Sn or In)/Pt ratio of 1.7/1 was chosen to promote alloy formation and enhance dehydrogenation activity. The metal loadings of 3 wt% are higher than those used in industry[21] but allow to balance adequate dehydrogenation activity with the ability to perform qualitative characterization. Mesoporous MgAl2O4 was used as support because of its stability, porosity, and balanced acid-base properties.[9,18,36–38] The catalysts were subjected to H2/CO2 and O2/H2 treatments and studied by in situ Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (QXAS) and Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP). This revealed that consecutive O2/H2 cycles, emulating typical catalyst regeneration, led to sintering for Pt:In, while the average composition of the Pt-In alloy remained unaffected. For Pt:Sn, the average Sn fraction in the alloyed phase increased, while no sintering was observed. Under pure CO2, In oxidised and segregated more easily from the alloyed NPs than Sn. In simultaneous presence of H2 and CO2 (RWGS), the alloy phases of Pt:Sn and Pt:In were largely maintained. For Pt:Sn specifically, combined Modulation-Excitation QXAS and TAP revealed that the prevailing interaction between H2 and CO2 does not involve theredox behaviour of solid intermediates (Sn/SnOx). Instead, the interaction proceeds through a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. This implies that Eq. (1) and Eq. (2) proceed in a sequential manner, as opposed to the type of interaction shown in Eq. (3) .[24,25] For Pt:In, no mechanism could be discerned due to the high volatility of In, which led to a highly dynamic structural behaviour of the Pt-In NPs. The next step is to link these identified material properties with the catalytic activity in CO2-PDH. This introduces three research questions: - Can the NP surface be detailed, building upon the NP-averaged properties identified in the preceding work?[31] - Can structural changes in the NP alloys be linked with propane conversion, propylene selectivity and carbon formation? - What is the influence of CO2 on propylene and carbon formation? For this purpose, the same three catalysts from the preceding work[31] − monometallic Pt, Pt:Sn and Pt:In − are further investigated, starting from the same sample states as defined in that study. Further characterization is undertaken through CO-DRIFTS, allowing to link the NP-averaged properties obtained from QXAS with the surface properties of the NPs. The catalysts are examined for their performance in CO2-PDH, while non-oxidative PDH and RWGS experiments serve as reference cases. Especially, the RWGS experiments allow for the assessment of the performance difference between non-oxidative PDH and CO2-PDH caused by an anticipated thermodynamic equilibrium shift. In addition, the effect of multiple O2/H2 cycles on the NP properties and catalyst performance is analysed, emulating typical catalyst regeneration steps. It is anticipated that O2/H2 cycles will affect the promoter composition in the alloyed NPs[12,23,39,40], as was confirmed through QXAS for Pt:Sn.[31] For CO2-PDH, the effect of the CO2:C3H8 feed ratio is studied. From QXAS results of the prior RWGS experiments, it is anticipated that this feed ratio should only affect the alloy phases to a slight extent.[31] Additionally, a fourth sample with 3 wt% Pt and 6 wt% In (Pt:6In) is examined with respect to the formation and removal of carbon through TEM-EDX mapping and in experiments where the feed gas is cycled between C3H8 and an oxidant (CO2 or O2). An analogous experiment for a Pt-Sn catalyst has already been reported.[23] 2 Materials & methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Four supported Pt-based catalysts are studied: Pt/MgAl2O4 (monometallic Pt), bimetallic Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 (Pt:Sn) and two bimetallic Pt:In/MgAl2O4 samples (Pt:In and Pt:6In). The Pt loading was 3 wt% for all catalysts. On the bimetallic samples, the promoter loading was 3 wt%, except for Pt:6In, which contained 6 wt% In. The porous MgAl2O4 support was synthesized through co-precipitation, followed by a drying step and calcination in air at 923 K. Metals were loaded via co-impregnation, followed by a drying step and calcination in air at 903 K. The sample state obtained after calcination is termed “As Prepared”. These samples are the same starting materials used in the previous QXAS experiments.[31] Further details regarding sample preparation are described elsewhere.[23,31] 2.2 CO-DRIFTS Extensive characterization of the materials has been performed by means of N2 physisorption, ICP-OES, SEM-EDX and QXAS.[31] In this work, CO-DRIFTS was additionally performed to track the alloy composition at the nanoparticle (NP) surface across regenerative O2/H2 cycles. The sample states probed with CO-DRFTS correspond to the “After TPR” and “After ME” states analysed with QXAS in prior work.[31] The applied methodology is analogous to past work on Pt-based catalysts.[39] Each sample was pretreated ex situ with 1, 5 or 10 O2/H2 regeneration cycles at 873 K. The samples were then mixed with KBr in a catalyst/KBr mass ratio of 1/20 to ensure a good signal-to-noise ratio. This diluted sample was transferred to a Tensor 27 apparatus (Bruker) with RockSolid interferometer, KBr beamsplitter and Specac Selector™ DRIFTS cell. To remove adsorbates and ensure the formation of metallic Pt and Pt-M alloys, the samples were pretreated at room temperature (RT) through 60 Nml/min He exposure, followed by in situ H2-TPR. A ramp rate of 10 K/min up to 723 K with 30 min dwell time was employed, using flows of 3.0 Nml/min H2 and 57.0 Nml/min He. This was followed by cooling down to 323 K under the same gas flow. The gas flow was then switched back to 60 Nml/min He for background measurements. Next, a 60 Nml/min gas flowof 1 mol% CO in He was maintained for 60 min. Finally, a set of 100 scans was collected with ascanning velocity of 20 kHz, under 60 Nml/min He. Averaging over all scans was performed to improve the signal-to-noise ratio. All scans were taken in absorbance mode from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 2 cm−1. Data analysis was performed with the OPUS 7.2 software (Bruker). 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements 2.3.1 Reactor setup All activity tests were performed at 121.3 kPa and isothermally at 873 K in a quartz fixed bed reactor with an internal diameter of 7.5 mm, housed inside an electric furnace. For each experiment, a catalyst mass of 0.100 g was diluted with 0.500 g α-Al2O3 (both 100–150 µm sieve fraction). The sample was kept in position by means of a quartz wool plug. The temperature of the catalyst bed and that of the external reactor wall at the bed position were measured via K-type thermocouples. Calibrated Bronckhorst mass flow controllers were used to control the gas feed. The reactor configuration allowed gas feed changes to be imposed as a step function. The absence of mass transfer limitations was assessed through the criteria of Carberry[41] and Weisz-Prater[42], while the absence of heat transport limitations was assessed through the criteria of Mears[43]. Prior to the activity measurements, an empty quartz reactor, as well as α-Al2O3 and MgAl2O4, were tested under reaction conditions to confirm the absence of thermal contributions and setup effects to the measured activity. 2.3.2 Catalyst activation and O2/H2 regeneration cycles All samples were activated through an in situ H2-TPR pretreatment, employing a 10 K/min rampto 873 K with 30 min dwell time. Volumetric flow rates of 15 Nml/min H2 and 90 Nml/min Ar were used. Next, the gas feed was switched to pure Ar at 873 K for 1 h, with a flow rate identical to the total flow rate of the corresponding dehydrogenation reactions (150 Nml/min or 200 Nml/min). A single O2/H2 regeneration cycle, termed “regen”, consists of an in situ exposure to 10 Nml/min O2 and 90 Nml/min Ar, followed by exposure to 15 Nml/min H2 and 90 Nml/min Ar, emulating catalyst regeneration conditions. The exposure to O2 subsequent to thereaction was maintained for 10 min to ensure complete removal of accumulated carbon. During this step, the carbon removal is quantified by monitoring the m/z = 44 signal of CO2 on a calibrated mass spectrometer. Similarly, the final H2 step before a new activity test was performed for 10 min to ensure a metallic state of the catalyst. All other O2 and H2 steps were maintained for 5 min each. Since calcination was performed in O2 (air) at elevated temperature, the first exposure to H2 in the H2-TPR activation step leads to the “1 regen” sample state, corresponding to the “After TPR” state probed in prior QXAS experiments.[31] 2.3.3 Dehydrogenation reactions 2.3.3.1 Non-oxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) Non-oxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) was performed to benchmark the activity of the samples for their typical application. A feed of 40 Nml/min C3H8, 40 Nml/min H2 and 120 Nml/min Ar was applied, yielding a space–time W cat / F C 3 H 8 0 of 3.36 k g c a t ∙ s ∙ m o l C 3 H 8 - 1 . Reactions were performed on samples in the states of “1 regen”, “5 regen”, “10 regen” and “15 regen”. Each reaction was maintained for 90 min time-on-stream (TOS). It must be noted that this work aims to probe the effect of the material properties on the catalytic performance. To induce changes in the catalyst material within perceptible timescales, the employed propane-based Weight Hour Space Velocity (WHSV, 47.1 h - 1 ), was considerably higher than the values typically reported in PDH studies (e.g. 4.7 h - 1 by Motagamwala et al.[11] and 0.64 h - 1 by Yan et al.[44]). 2.3.3.2 CO2-assisted PDH (CO2-PDH) Two different experimental schemes were applied while co-feeding CO2: “ratio” and “regeneration” experiments. In both schemes, the space–time of propane W cat / F C 3 H 8 0 was kept identical to the one of the non-oxidative PDH experiments with 3.36 k g c a t ∙ s ∙ m o l C 3 H 8 - 1 . Ratio experiments involved CO2-PDH runs with different CO2:C3H8 molar feed ratiosto assess the effect of CO2 partial pressure on dehydrogenation activity and catalyst deactivation and make the connection with theprior characterization of the catalyst structure under different oxidative and reductive atmospheres.[31] A fixed flow rate of 40 Nml/min C3H8 was employed, while the CO2 flow rate varied from 0, 5, 10 to 20 Nml/min (yielding CO2:C3H8 feed ratios of 0.000:1, 0.125:1, 0.250:1 and 0.500:1, respectively). Ar was used as a balance to maintain a total flow rate of 150 Nml/min. Each reaction was run for 30 min time-on-stream (TOS). Regeneration experiments involved CO2-PDH runs at the 0.125:1 CO2:C3H8 molar feed ratio after subjecting the samples to 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 15 and 20 in situ O2/H2 regeneration cycles. This experiment hence assesses the structural stability of the bimetallic Pt-based alloys and the consequences for dehydrogenation activity, again connecting with prior work.[31] These experiments were hence not performed on the monometallic Pt sample. Flow rates of 40 Nml/min C3H8, 5 Nml/min CO2 and 105 Nml/min Ar were employed. Each reaction was maintained for 20 min time-on-stream (TOS). 2.3.4 Reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) RWGS experiments were performed separately to assess the anticipated contribution of H2 removal by CO2 in the CO2-PDH reaction experiments. Different molar feed ratios of CO2:H2 (1:1, 1:2 and 1:3) were applied. The CO2 feed flow rate was maintained at 10 Nml/min while that of H2 was varied accordingly. Each time, Ar was added as a balance to obtain a total flow rate of 150 Nml/min. 2.3.5 Data analysis The reactor outlet was analysed through a combination of a Gas Chromatograph (GC, Thermo Scientific with TCD and FID) and aMass Spectrometer (MS, Omnistar Pfeiffer). GC data were quantified through Ar as aninternal standard (TCD). This allowed the quantification of CH4 on the same TCD channel. The obtained value for CH4 was transferred to the FID channel to quantify the signals for C2H6, C2H4, C2H2, C3H8 and C3H6. MS signals were recorded for all major fragments: 2 m/z for H2, 16 m/z for CH4, 18 m/z for H2O, 28 m/z for CO, 29 m/z for C3H8, 32 m/z for O2, 40 m/z for Ar, 41 m/z for C3H6 and 44 m/z for CO2. Correction for overlapping fragments proceeded through calibrations at room temperature (RT). The error on the carbon balance was verified using Eq. (6) , where n C , i is the carbon number of component i , F i 0 the molar inlet flow and F i the molar outlet flow of component i . In all reported experiments, the carbon balance closed within 95 % ( % C ≤ 5 % ). The conversion of a component i ( X i ) was calculated via Eq. (7) . The corresponding selectivity from reactant i towards product j ( S j i ) was calculated based on the conversion of i via Eq. (8) .[29] A space–time yield for product j ( STY j , mol j ∙ s - 1 ∙ mol Pt - 1 ) was defined through Eq. (9) , where n Pt is the molar amount of Pt present in the reactor. (6) % C = 100 ∙ ∑ i n C , i ∙ ( F i 0 - F i ) ∑ i n C , i ∙ F i 0 (7) X i = F i 0 - F i F i 0 (8) S j i = n C , j ∙ F j n C , i ∙ F i 0 - F i (9) STY j = F j n Pt 2.3.6 Equilibrium calculations Equilibrium conversions of C3H8 and CO2 were considered in the analysis of the RWGS and dehydrogenation reactions. The equilibrium values were estimated through a Gibbs-free energy minimization method in Aspen Plus V12.1, employing the NRTL property method.[45] Each time, a temperature of 873 K and a total pressure of 121.3 kPa were used, including Ar. C3H8 equilibrium conversions were calculated for non-oxidative PDH, considering only direct dehydrogenation of C3H8 occurs (Eq. (1) ). Equilibrium conversions in CO2-assisted PDH reactions assumed that direct dehydrogenation of C3H8 (Eq. (1) ) was followed by RWGS (Eq. (2) ).[28,31] CO2 equilibrium conversions were calculated for the RWGS reaction, using different CO2:H2 feed ratios: those of the dedicated RWGS experiments (constant CO2:H2 feed ratio of 1:1, 1:2 and 1:3) as well as those that would occur during CO2-PDH (CO2:H2 feed ratio varying in time). For the latter case, the H2 quantities were based on the conversion of C3H8 and the selectivity towards propylene during CO2-PDH. 3 Results 3.1 CO-DRIFTS The Pt-CO bond signatures in CO-DRIFTS are sensitive to geometric and electronic changes of the Pt species at the NP surface.[9,33,46–49] This is utilized to study the effect of catalyst regeneration cycles on the alloyed NPs. Samples were pretreated with repeated ex situ O2/H2 cycles and a final in situ H2-TPR. The results for Pt:Sn and Pt:In are depicted in Fig. 1 . The monometallic Pt sample shows a peak at 2063 cm−1, attributed to atop CO adsorption on Pt,[46,48,50] and a high-energy shoulder at 2083 cm−1, related to CO linearly adsorbed on well-defined crystal faces of Pt.[46,48 ] Moreover, a broad peak attributed to bridged CO adsorption is noted at 1800 cm−1.[9,48,49] The addition of a promoter element, however, leads to the disappearance of the 2083 cm−1 shoulder and the 1800 cm−1 feature, indicating a dilution of the Pt clusters by the promoter.[9,48] Moreover, adding a promoter element induces a peak shift from 2063 cm−1 towards lower energies. These shifts can either be electronically or geometrically induced. The direction of an electronically induced shift depends on the CO coverage.[48] Given the relatively long CO exposure (60 min) and high stability[47] of CO on Pt, high CO surface coverages[49,50] are assumed. Under these circumstances, a shift towards lower energies could indicate an electron donation from a promoter element towards Pt.[4,48] A geometrically induced shift towards lower energies would imply a decrease[50,51] in NP size, which was not observed for these samples.[31] Peak shifts are observed when comparing the CO-DRIFTS spectra across different O2/H2 regeneration cycles. For Pt:Sn, these shifts systematically go towards lower frequencies: from 2062 cm−1 (1 regeneration cycle) to 2053 cm−1 (10 regeneration cycles). Since the average NP size of Pt:Sn remains constant[31], the observed peak shift is assigned to an electronic origin, possibly linked to an increased Sn content in the Pt-Sn alloy.[40,48] EXAFS also indicated that, averaged over the whole Pt:Sn sample, the Sn content in the Pt-Sn alloy increased across O2/H2 cycles. The current observations from CO-DRIFTS confirm that the Sn content increases not only on average but also at the NP surface. For Pt:In, an initial shift towards higher frequencies is followed by a shift towards lower frequencies (from 2060 cm−1 to 2062 cm−1 to 2057 cm−1). This is consistent with the dynamic restructuring of the Pt:In sample[31], possibly aided by the high volatility of In. A constant average composition of the Pt-In alloy and increasing NP size were noted through EXAFS analysis. The initial shift to higher frequencies in CO-DRIFTS can therefore be ascribed to a dominant contribution of NP sintering, whereas the subsequent shift to lower frequencies would imply a more dominant contribution of a more In-rich alloy at the NP surface.[49] Since a constant average Pt-In alloy phase is maintained for Pt:In[31], this would mean that a concomitant In-poor alloy phase must have been formed in the bulk of the NPs. Similar observations have been made by Wegener et al. on Pt-In/SiO2 catalysts.[32] The combination of the prior QXAS results[31] with the current CO-DRIFTS results thus allows to discern a promoter enrichment at the NP surface, which was not possible through QXAS experiments alone. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Non-oxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) PDH with H2 co-feed was performed after pretreatment with 1, 5 10 and 15 O2/H2 regeneration cycles. The results are shown in Fig. 2 and serve to establish a benchmark for the activity and stability of the samples. In the “1 regen” state, both catalysts reach similar STY C 3 H 6 values of ∼0.45 mol C 3 H 6 ∙ s - 1 ∙ mol Pt - 1 , as they both reach X C 3 H 8 values of ∼25 % and S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 values above 95 %. The propylene selectivity of Pt:In is slightly higher than that of Pt:Sn. Given the similar X C 3 H 8 values for Pt:Sn and Pt:In in the “1 regen” state, this selectivity difference is not a conversion effect, which aligns with the work of Sun et al.. These authors studied comparable PtSn/Mg(Al)O and Pt/Mg(In)(Al)O catalysts[7,12] and found that changing the promoter from Sn to In lead to better selectivity and stability for non-oxidative PDH. In the “1 regen” state, the performance of Pt:In indeed appears more stable than that of Pt:Sn. Across multiple O2/H2 regeneration cycles, however, Pt:Sn maintains a more stable performance. When moving from the “1 regen” to the “5 regen” state, X C 3 H 8 of Pt:Sn increases slightly with a concomitant decrease of S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 . Further increasing the number of O2/H2 cycles leads to a slight decrease of X C 3 H 8 and a concomitant increase of S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 . When considering the Pt:Sn STY C 3 H 6 profiles, the effect of multiple regeneration cycles remains moderate. The Sn enrichment at the NP surface could explain the observed trends. Given the constant NP size and increased Sn fraction in both NP bulk[31] and NP surface upon O2/H2 treatments, it follows that the fraction of surface Pt atoms decreases. This ‘Pt dilution’ at the NP surface will lower X C 3 H 8 while simultaneously suppressing structure-sensitive side reactions. From an electronic viewpoint, desorption of C3H6 will be promoted, increasing S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 . [4,16] For Pt:In, X C 3 H 8 continuously decreases across O2/H2 cycles, and this over a larger interval when compared to Pt:Sn. In contrast, S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 remains constant around 98 %. QXAS[31] and current CO-DRIFTS results imply that O2/H2 treatments yield a combination of NP sintering and increased In content at the NP surface. Both effects will decrease the number of accessible Pt sites, coinciding with the decreasing trend of X C 3 H 8 . However, the increased In content at the NP surface appears to have no impact on S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 . The accumulated amount of carbon after the PDH reactions is shown in Fig. 3 . For Pt:Sn, the amount of carbon formed mainly coincides with the trends in S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 . For Pt:In, the carbon formation increases continuously with increasing number of O2/H2 cycles. Moreover, the Pt:In catalyst performs worse than Pt:Sn by one order of magnitude. The magnitude of this difference is unexpected, especially considering Pt:In maintained S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 values around 98 %, and considering H2 is being co-fed (adsorbed H2 assists towards the rehydrogenation of propylidyne, a coke precursor and decomposition product of propylene[52]). Also, the works of Sun et al.[12] and Tolek et al.[34] do not anticipate such large discrepancies in carbon formation. This carbon formation can be linked to Pt, based on other studies[7,12,52] and on the negligible X C 3 H 8 observed when testing the bare MgAl2O4 support (2.3.1). A possible explanation for the high amount of carbon formation on Pt:In can be found in its specific NP structure. Prior work reported the vaporization of In and a concurrent dynamic restructuring of the NPs under a reductive H2 atmosphere.[31] This In volatility can facilitate the transfer of the formed carbon from the NP surface towards the support surface. A similar carbon migration was previously described by Redekop et al..[52,53] This hypothesis is further supported by the stable X C 3 H 8 profiles and high S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 values observed for Pt:In within each reaction run (Fig. 2b), implying that the amount of accessible Pt sites remained relatively constant within each reaction. 3.2.2 Reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) One of the advantages of CO2-PDH over non-oxidative PDH is a thermodynamic equilibrium shift towards propylene caused by the consumption of H2 via the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. (1) and Eq. (2) ).[22,24] Consequently, part of the effect of CO2-PDH redox conditions on the alloyed NPs can be emulated via RWGS (i.e. the simultaneous presence of reducing H2 and oxidizing CO2). Since the presence of hydrocarbons in an actual CO2-PDH environment causes carbon formation, a complex interplay can arise between carbon deposits, X C 3 H 8 , X C O 2 and alloy stability. Hence, dedicated RWGS experiments are discussed first to construct an understanding of the catalyst’s inherent RWGS activity and alloy stability without the added complexity of dehydrogenation activity and carbon formation. The experiments were performed with volumetric CO2:H2 feed ratios of 1:3, 1:2 and 1:1, respectively, yielding corresponding CO2 equilibrium conversions of 59.8 %, 51.6 % and 37.8 %. The results are depicted in Fig. 4 and show that CO2 equilibrium conversions are reached for both Pt:Sn and Pt:In. Moreover, both catalysts maintain stable X C O 2 profiles for the entire 30 min TOS. Only a slight decrease is noted for the 1:3 feed ratio on Pt:Sn. This may indicate that the active Pt-Sn and Pt-In alloy phases do not deactivate to a notable extent within the measured timescale. Preservation of the Pt-Sn and Pt-In alloys during the RWGS reaction aligns with other work, which demonstrated that the alloy phases were only oxidized to a minor extent during RWGS.[31] This was true for 20 min TOS and comparable GHSVs. Moreover, the corresponding CO2:H2 feed ratios (1:1, 1:0.33 and 1:0.20) yielded more oxidative atmospheres than the feed ratios employed in the current work (1:3, 1:2 and 1:1), and thus they should have had a larger influence on the alloy stability. Given that the partial pressures of CO2 and H2 during CO2-PDH experiments will be comparable to those of the current RWGS experiments, it is anticipated that RWGS equilibrium will also be reached during CO2-PDH experiments. One important difference will be the varying amount of H2 in the system during a true CO2-PDH reaction since the presence of H2 is tied with X C 3 H 8 through Eq. (1) . Catalyst deactivation will cause a decreasing X C 3 H 8 and/or altering S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 with increasing TOS. With a decreasing presence of H2 and a constant feed of CO2, the RWGS equilibrium composition will change accordingly, rendering the reaction environment increasingly more oxidative with increasing TOS. Since promoter oxidation did occur in pure CO2,[31] a certain threshold value of CO2:H2 may exist above which promoter oxidation becomes eminent (e.g. above the most oxidative ratio of 1:0.20). Such promoter oxidation would initiate deactivation, consisting of promoter oxides blocking active Pt sites, while simultaneous alloy segregation will increase carbon formation. Both phenomena will lower the dehydrogenation activity, further increasing the in situ CO2:H2 ratio and thus promoting even further oxidation of the promoter elements. Also, the beneficial RWGS activity will lower since the interaction between H2 and CO2 on Pt:Sn dominantly proceeds on the reduced metal surface, and not through catalyst lattice oxygen.[31] 3.2.3 CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation (CO2-PDH) 3.2.3.1 Ratio experiments CO2-PDH reactions with different CO2:C3H8 volumetric feed ratios were performed. Such varying feed ratios could affect the integrity of the alloyed NPs, albeit to a minor extent.[31] The space–time yields of propylene ( STY C 3 H 6 ) are shown in Fig. 5 , while the corresponding propane conversions ( X C 3 H 8 ) and propylene selectivities ( S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 ) are shown in SI, Fig. S2 . S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 values above 95 % are obtained, and hence the TOS profiles of STY C 3 H 6 follow those of X C 3 H 8 . The beneficial effect of the promotion with Sn and In with respect to monometallic Pt is seen in Fig. 5. Across all feed ratios, the highest STY C 3 H 6 values and stability are noted for Pt:Sn. Pt:In displays similar STY C 3 H 6 values as Pt:Sn in the initial stages of the reaction, but this is followed by faster deactivation. The monometallic Pt sample consistently displays the worst performance as fast deactivation occurred within the first 100 s TOS, after which the STY C 3 H 6 profiles stabilize at values below 0.1 m o l C 3 H 6 ∙ s - 1 ∙ m o l P t - 1 . Multiple effects of increasing the CO2:C3H8 feed ratio can be distinguished. The 0.125:1 ratio results in an increased STY C 3 H 6 , increased X C 3 H 8 and slower deactivation for all catalysts when compared to not co-feeding CO2. A higher feed ratio of 0.250:1 results in an even better initial STY C 3 H 6 and X C 3 H 8 for Pt:Sn and Pt:In, but this is followed by faster deactivation. The latter is more extreme for Pt:In than for Pt:Sn. The 0.500:1 CO2:C3H8 feed ratio yields a STY C 3 H 6 comparable to not co-feeding CO2 for Pt:Sn. For Pt:In, an even worse performance is noted when compared to not feeding CO2, as rapid initial deactivation occurs. After 450 s TOS, STY C 3 H 6 values similar to those of the monometallic Pt catalyst are obtained. Several phenomena can contribute to the observed trends. Theoretically, a performance improvement with co-feeding CO2 is anticipated through a thermodynamic shift via the RWGS reaction and through carbon oxidation.[22] Simultaneously, CO2 can amplify catalyst deactivation in two major ways. (i) In certain CO2:H2 ratios, the alloys remain stable. On an alloyed Pt-Sn surface, a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of interaction between CO2 and H2 was discerned.[31] Competitive adsorption phenomena between CO2 and H2 in RWGS can be important in this context.[6] The CO2:H2 ratio is coupled with the CO2:C3H8 feed ratio. Analogously, competition for the active sites between CO2 and C3H8 can play a role. (ii) In more oxidative atmospheres, i.e. with increasing CO2:H2 concentration ratios, oxidation of the promoter can occur, leading to segregation of the alloy phases. The latter can be anticipated based on the observed deactivation, but was also evidenced from previous in situ QXAS results under CO2-TPO and isothermal oxidation with CO2.[31] Additionally, deactivation phenomena not necessarily inherent to the CO2 co-feed are expected, such as NP sintering for Pt:In and carbon formation (fraction not oxidized by CO2). In fact, promoter oxidation is linked with carbon formation as CO2 can trigger alloy phase segregation, which leads to increased carbon formation and subsequent activity loss (3.2.2). Finally, dry reforming of propane (Eq. (4) ) is not considered based on the molar CO2:C3H8 consumption being lower than the reaction stoichiometry of 3:1. Confirmation of RWGS activity during the CO2-PDH experiments is found in the MS signals for H2O at the reactor outlet (m/z = 18, SI, Fig. S2 ) in combination with the CO2 conversions (Fig. 6 ). Dedicated RWGS experiments under analogous reactor conditions allowed to reach equilibrium CO2 conversions (Fig. 4). The RWGS equilibrium that would occur throughout the current CO2-PDH experiments can be estimated by assuming all produced H2 to react with all co-fed CO2. The produced amount of H2 can be estimated from X C 3 H 8 (Eq. (1) ), assuming S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 equals 100 % (actual: >95 %, Fig. S2 ). The dotted lines in Fig. 6 represent the thus obtained equilibrium conversions of CO2 in RWGS. The comparison reveals that, in some scenarios, the actual CO2 conversion during CO2-PDH is even higher than what could be achieved through RWGS alone. The excess CO2 consumption must, therefore, arise from a different process than RWGS, which could be theoxidation of carbon (Eq. (5) ) and/or oxidation of the promoter element. These phenomena can be discerned through the analysis of the carbon formation (Fig. 7 ), the catalyst deactivation profiles (Fig. 5 and SI, Fig. S2 ), and the comparison of excess CO2 conversion with the amount of promoter element present in the reactor. First, an order of magnitude comparison can be made between the excess CO2 conversion and the amount of promoter element present in the reactor. The lowest CO2 feed flow of 5 Nml/min equals a molar feed flow of ∼223 µmol/min. Considering an excess CO2 conversion of ∼5 percentage point above the RWGS equilibrium, it means that ∼(0.05∙223) ≈ 11 µmol/min of CO2 gets consumed in excess. The highest CO2 feed flow of 20 Nml/min equals a molar feed flow of ∼892 µmol/min. An excess CO2 conversion of ∼5 percentage point then equals ∼45 µmol/min. The reactor contains 0.1 g catalyst containing 3 wt% promoter, or a total of ∼25 µmol Sn or In. This shows that the excess CO2 consumption alone could fully oxidize the present amount of promoter within a few minutes. However, Fig. 6 depicts an excess CO2 consumption across much longer TOS periods, or even across the full 1800 s TOS. This shows that promoter oxidation alone cannot explain the excess CO2 conversion from Fig. 6. The oxidation of carbon as a source of CO2 consumption can be assessed through analysis of the amount of accumulated carbon, depicted in Fig. 7. These trends largely invert those of S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 , without obvious connection to the CO2:C3H8 feed ratio. The monometallic Pt sample yields the lowest S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 , with concomitant highest amount of carbon accumulation. Yet, the excess CO2 consumption observed in Fig. 6 would imply a significant occurrence of carbon oxidation to CO (Eq. (5) ), since CO2 consumption through Pt oxidation is unlikely.[31] Pt:In has the highest S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 of all samples, with values close to 100 % for all feed ratios. This coincides with the low and nearly constant amount of carbon accumulation on this sample across the different feeds. However, carbon accumulation is not absent, with values within the same order of magnitude as the other catalysts. Only the 0.500:1 feed ratio yields a distinctly lower amount of accumulated carbon. Fig. 6 shows that this is the only feed ratio that yields a surplus in CO2 conversion beyond the RWGS equilibrium. Similarly, for Pt:Sn, the co-feed of CO2 decreases the carbon accumulation, except for the 0.250:1 ratio. Fig. 6 shows no surplus CO2 conversion beyond the RWGS equilibrium for this same ratio. However, the amount of accumulated carbon does not take the time character of the carbon formation into account. Typically, more carbon is formed in the initial stages of the reaction, as both selective and unselective Pt sites are accessible. The unselective Pt sites (e.g. undercoordinated sites) quickly get blocked by strongly adsorbed carbon.[23] This aligns with separate reaction experiments on a fourth sample (3 wt% Pt and 6 wt% In, Pt:6In). The combination with STEM-EDX mapping shows that CO2 is unable to oxidize carbon from these undercoordinated sites. This is further elaborated in the Supporting Information (SI, Figs. S6 and S7 ). For the bimetallic samples, adding an analysis of the STY C 3 H 6 profiles to the aforementioned arguments allows to explain the origin of excess CO2 consumption. The STY C 3 H 6 profiles show that deactivation proceeds notably faster during CO2-PDH (Fig. 5) than during non-oxidative PDH (Fig. 2 , a3 and b3). This is especially the case for Pt:In. Consider the 0.250:1 CO2:C3H8 feed ratio on this sample. The removal of produced H2 through RWGS causes an initial superior STY C 3 H 6 (Fig. 5) and production of H2O (SI, Fig. S2 ), but once X C 3 H 8 drops, deactivation proceeds faster than during the 0.125:1 feed ratio. Note the crossing between the RWGS equilibrium and the experimental CO2 conversion at 650 s TOS in Fig. 6. This can result from a change in sample state, such as the oxidation of the promoter element, which would not occur during non-oxidative PDH. The former process leads to alloy segregation, thereby promoting carbon formation, which is then probed as excess CO2 conversion. Prior QXAS results showed that oxidation of the promoter element and concomitant alloy segregation are possible under certain CO2:H2 ratios.[31] The CO2:H2 ratio will increase with increasing TOS during CO2-PDH, since the presence of H2 is tied with a decreasing trend of X C 3 H 8 . This phenomenon could thus be an example of deactivation being initiated by promoter oxidation, as described in section 3.2.2. This phenomenon is most notable for the 0.500:1 feed ratio: Pt:In shows fast initial deactivation towards monometallic Pt behaviour, implying that the Pt-In alloy phase has most likely fully segregated due to In oxidation. The Pt:Sn sample appears more stable in the 0.500:1 feed ratio, showing faster deactivation than other CO2:C3H8 feed ratios, but not towards full monometallic Pt behaviour. For the specific case of Pt:In, the volatility of In can also contribute to the observed deactivation through loss of In and NP sintering. These phenomena would occur in the initial stages of the reaction, where the atmosphere is more reductive (i.e. lower CO2:H2 ratio). Finally, an effect of competitive adsorption between CO2 and C3H8 may be discerned for the monometallic Pt sample. While at first, a beneficial effect of carbon oxidation and RWGS is observed at low CO2 concentrations (0.125:1 vs. 0.000:1), employing higher CO2 concentrations results in a decreased dehydrogenation activity. Since no promoter oxidation occurs and carbon is removed, this activity decrease can stem from competition between CO2 and C3H8 for available Pt sites. The activity results of the bimetallic samples do not explicitly identify competitive adsorption phenomena, as they include the additional deactivation effect of promoter oxidation. On all three samples, the best improvement is noted for the 0.125:1 feed ratio. The fact that the 0.250:1 ratio performs better than 0.125:1 in the initial reaction stage implies that using lower ratios of CO2 would not improve the process at these specific conditions. At the same time, deactivation proceeds faster at the 0.250:1 ratio. Hence, the 0.125:1 ratio will be chosen for the O2/H2 regeneration experiments. Note that CO2:C3H8 feed ratios of 1:1 to 5:1 have been used for CO2-PDH in studies that were focused on redox catalysts,[24,54,55] and that the current X C 3 H 8 values remain far below the attainable equilibrium (SI, Fig. S2-1 ). 3.2.3.2 Regeneration experiments Combining CO-DRIFTS and QXAS[31] results revealed that O2/H2 cycles affect the promoter content at the NP surface. Therefore, an effect on the dehydrogenation activity isanticipated after such regeneration cycles.[7,12] The STY C 3 H 6 profiles are shown in Fig. 8 , while X C 3 H 8 , S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 and the H2O MS signal (m/z = 18) are shown in SI, Fig. S3 . The O2/H2 cycles indeed have a clear effect on the activity. After each cycle, a significant fraction of the initial activity is restored. However, successive O2/H2 cycles also induce permanent deactivation, and yield different deactivation profiles. A means of numerically comparing these deactivation profiles can be provided by defining the rate of deactivation r d ′ ( t ) via Eq. (10) , assuming an n -th order power law.[56] This yields a deactivation rate constant D with units of s−1. Here, a ( t ) is defined by Eq. (11) as a dimensionless catalyst activity, in which - r C 3 H 8 ′ ( t ) is defined by Eq. (12) as the rate of propane consumption. The latter has units of reacted mol C 3 H 8 ∙ s - 1 ∙ mol Pt - 1 . The integral form of Eq. (10) was fitted to the experimental a ( t ) data to obtain numerical values for D . The most consistent and best overall fit statistics are obtained when assuming a deactivation of zeroth order for Pt:Sn ( n = 0, linear decay)[35], and first order for Pt:In ( n = 1, exponential decay), see Fig. 9 and SI, Fig. S5 and Tables S2-S3 . (10) r d ′ ( t ) = - da ( t ) dt = D ∙ a ( t ) n (11) a ( t ) = - r C 3 H 8 ′ ( t ) - r C 3 H 8 ′ ( t = 0 ) (12) - r C 3 H 8 ′ t = F C 3 H 8 0 - F C 3 H 8 n Pt D increases for both samples (i.e. faster deactivation) with increasing number of O2/H2 cycles. Pt:Sn experiences a distinct change in D and STY C 3 H 6 (Fig. 8) when moving from the “5 regen” to the “7 regen” state. Concomitantly, a distinct decrease in X C 3 H 8 and a change in TOS profiles of S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 are noted after the “5 regen” state, although S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 is generally maintained around 98 % (SI, Fig. S3 ). Analogous observations are made for Pt:In, except that the deactivation is more severe than for Pt:Sn. Namely, the value of D for Pt:In increases more uniformly and across a larger interval with anincreasing number of O2/H2 cycles. A concomitant and relatively uniform decrease of STY C 3 H 6 is noted. Also, S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 (SI, Fig. S3 ) shows a decreasing trend with increasing O2/H2 cycles. Moreover, S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 starts decreasing with TOS after the “5 regen” state of Pt:In. Foregoing analysis of the ratio experiments considered several phenomena that could contribute to the catalyst deactivation. A similar analysis will be made herebut with an additional focus on phenomena occurring across regeneration cycles instead of solely focusing on phenomena occurring within one TOS run. For example, the ratio experiments demonstrated that CO2 was mainly consumed through RWGS and carbon oxidation, with carbon formation being reinforced by promoter oxidation. Based on CO-DRIFTS and QXAS[31] results, the current O2/H2 regeneration cycles lead to increased promoter content at the NP surface. Thus, this could entail a larger extent of promoter oxidation and consequently faster deactivation. Inherently, a changing promoter content can directly affect PDH activity through both electronic and geometric effects.[4,7,12] For Pt:In, NP sintering must be considered again during a single reaction as well as across regeneration cycles.[31] Analogous to the ratio experiments, the CO2 conversion can be analysed along with the STY C 3 H 6 trends from Fig. 8. The experimental CO2 conversions (Fig. 10 ) on Pt:Sn consistently show a surplus compared to the in situ RWGS equilibrium (SI, Fig. S4 ). This surplus may be due to carbon oxidation and/or to Sn oxidation by CO2. The amount of accumulated carbon is shown in Fig. 12 and mainly correlates with the trends of the X C 3 H 8 and STY C 3 H 6 profiles, rather than the S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 profiles. This makes it difficult to directly link the excess CO2 consumption (Fig. 10) to carbon oxidation based on accumulated carbon alone. However, the excess CO2 consumption can be linked to carbon oxidation when also considering the possibility of promoter oxidation and concomitant alloy segregation. To his end, the excess CO2 consumption is isolated in Fig. 11 as the experimental CO2 conversion vs. the RWGS equilibrium. The obtained ratios are estimates, but the trends over TOS remain informative, nonetheless. With increasing TOS, the excess CO2 consumption becomes larger. For Pt:Sn, this is especially true after the “5 regen” state, the same state after which the S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 profiles start showing decreasing trends with TOS (SI, Fig. S3 ) and where D distinctly increases. If this coincides with an increased Sn fraction at the NP surface, then oxidation of Sn could induce such deactivation behaviour since the benefits of the Pt-Sn alloy upon S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 are lost. Simultaneously, an Sn enriched surface, as would occur after “5 regen”, would be more prone to oxidation by CO2. For Pt:In, CO2 conversions are below the RWGS equilibrium from the “1 regen” up to the “10 regen” states. Excess CO2 consumption is only noted for the states “15 regen” and “20 regen”, the same states that show a distinctly lower STY C 3 H 6 profile. Once excess CO2 consumption does occur for Pt:In, it increases more rapidly with TOS. For example, the inflection point at ∼400 s TOS coincides with the point at which X C 3 H 8 starts reaching a plateau for “15 regen” and “20 regen” (SI, Fig. S3 ). These results provide an additional example of catalyst deactivation being initiated by promoter oxidation as described in sections 3.2.2 and 3.2.3.1, with more pronounced effects for Pt:In. The increased promoter content at the NP surface upon O2/H2 cycling will then initiate this deactivation more quickly. All these results show the detrimental effect of promoter oxidation upon the catalyst activity during CO2-PDH, even at a relatively low CO2:C3H8 feed ratio of 0.125:1. Therefore, the Pt:Sn and Pt:In catalysts show limited scope for further application in CO2-PDH in their present form. Nevertheless, supported noble metal-based catalysts generally show higher activity than redox catalysts.[29] For example, the current Pt:Sn and Pt:In samples still show viable initial activities and selectivities. Pt-Sn and Pt-In systems can therefore still be used as starting point for further optimization.[28,29,57,58] Future enhancements could focus on maintaining the integrity of the alloyed NPs. For example, the approach of Xing et al. involves the incorporation of one or more modifying transition metals into the alloy, yielding ternary (e.g. Pt-In-Co[30]) or high-entropy[59] alloys to improve catalytic activity, selectivity and stability. Furthermore, the activity and stability can be tailored by changing the support material. Strong metal-support interactions can stabilize alloyed NPs, while support materials with specific properties can influence the mechanism of CO2 activation.[29,58] Instead of a basic non-reducible MgAl2O4 support, a reducible oxide like CeO2 or ZrO2 could lower the energy barrier for CO2 activation[29,57], potentially reducing operating temperatures. This in turn may have beneficial effects on the NP stability.[31] Finally, suggestions for catalyst development should be evaluated together with the operation mode of the reactor (co-feeding CO2 vs. chemical looping) and the associated partial pressures of CO2, H2 and hydrocarbons.[23,31,58] 4 Conclusion Pt:Sn and Pt:In catalysts were tested for CO2-PDH at 873 K and atmospheric pressure. The effect of varying CO2:C3H8 feed ratios and repeated O2/H2 regeneration cycles upon the propylene formation was analysed. Non-oxidative PDH and RWGS experiments, as well as a monometallic Pt catalyst, served as reference cases. Finally, CO-DRIFTS further detailed Pt species at the nanoparticle (NP) surface. Connection with QXAS and TAP results from other work allowed to relate restructuring of the Pt-Sn and Pt-In NPs to changes in propylene formation. During CO2-PDH, CO2 was mainly consumed through the RWGS reaction. The lower CO2:C3H8 feed ratios of 0.125:1 and 0.250:1 resulted in an increased STY C 3 H 6 when compared to not co-feeding CO2, but only in the initial stages of the reaction. The 0.500:1 feed ratio showed the worst performance. Additionally, CO2 conversions beyond the RWGS equilibrium were observed. While oxidation of the promoter element by CO2 occurs, it has a minor contribution in the excess CO2 consumption. The ensuing loss of the Pt-based alloys decreases propylene selectivity and increases carbon formation, which is the primary cause of the CO2 conversions beyond the RWGS equilibrium. These phenomena increase the in situ CO2:H2 ratio, leading to further promoter oxidation and further activity loss, hence initiating deactivation. This effect is most pronounced on Pt:In, as In is more easily oxidizable than Sn. CO-DRIFTS disclosed that regenerative O2/H2 cycles at 873 K increased the Sn content throughout the entire NP f or Pt:Sn. For Pt:In, the In content was increased at the NP surface, together with In depletion from the NP bulk. This (surface) promoter enrichment accelerates deactivation for both catalyststhrough promoter oxidation in CO2-PDH. Pt:Sn remains the most stable catalyst in terms of structure and activity. It is known for Pt:Sn that CO2 dominantly participates in RWGS and carbon oxidation through a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of mechanism, requiring a reduced form of the Pt-Sn NPs. Also propylene formation benefits from Pt-Sn alloy formation. However, even with the lowest CO2:C3H8 feed ratio on Pt:Sn, (surface) promoter oxidation and consequent alloy segregation occur. To stabilize the Pt-based alloys, future research could focus on alternative supports and incorporating additional modifying elements. 5 Associated content • TCD profiles of H2 Temperature Programmed Reduction. • Ratio experiments results: propane conversion ( X C 3 H 8 ), propylene selectivity ( S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 ) and qualitative H2O formation for Pt:Sn, Pt:In and monometallic Pt. • Regeneration experiments results: propane conversion ( X C 3 H 8 ), propylene selectivity ( S C 3 H 6 C 3 H 8 ), qualitative H2O formation, CO2 equilibrium conversion in RWGS and fitted values for the deactivation rate constant in the case of zeroth, first and second order deactivation. • Experiments with alternating C3H8-oxidant cycles on a sample with higher In loading (3 wt% Pt and 6 wt% In, Pt:6In). The oxidants are CO2 and O2, allowing a detailed assessment of carbon removal. • Electron microscopy results on a sample with higher In loading (3 wt% Pt and 6 wt% In, Pt:6In): Dark Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (DF-STEM) and EDX mapping, supporting the experiments with alternating C3H8-oxidant cycles. coredata.dc:description: Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 and Pt:In/MgAl2O4 catalysts with 3 wt% Pt and 3 wt% Sn or In were tested for CO2-assisted propane dehydrogenation (CO2-PDH). This reaction was referenced against reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) and non-oxidative PDH, while CO-DRIFTS detailed the nanoparticle (NP) surface. Results were connected to a preceding study, focused on NP material properties using Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy and Temporal Analysis of Products. During CO2-PDH, CO2 was mainly consumed through RWGS. CO2 consumption beyond the RWGS equilibrium arose from carbon oxidation. Promoter oxidation by CO2 and the consequent loss of the Pt-based alloys induced carbon formation. This deactivation increased the in situ CO2:H2 ratio, further accelerating promoter oxidation and carbon formation. Repeated catalyst regeneration cycles increased the promoter concentration in the alloyed NPs. This occurred throughout the entire Pt:Sn NP, while for Pt:In, it was limited to the NP surface with concomitant NP bulk depletion. This promoter enrichment contributed to catalyst deactivation.
